Incident.Summary: MSP BK G DUI 23-013, TA 21-901A1ii DUI Per Se (HAYNES, AUSTIN COLE)

IncidentSuppNarrative.NarrativeText: 23-MSP-003563 Incident: MSP Barrack G DUI 23-013 TA 21-902(A)(1)ii Driving Under the Influence of Alcohol Per Se Date/ Time: 01/28/2023, 1421 hours Location of Offense: S/B BOLLINGER RD, N/O HOOK RD, FIKSBURG, CARROLL COUNTY, MD. Incident recorded on AXON digital recording system assigned to G-39 and AXON body camera assigned to M/Tpr Fair. Minors in Vehicle:NO PBT: 0.11 BrAC at 1450 hours on 01/28/2023 EVIDENTIARY TEST:0.11 BrAC at 1540 hours on 01/28/2023 DRE (Drug Recognition Expert): N/A Weather: cloudy, approximately 50 degrees Fahrenheit Prior Offense: NO Qualifications: -Maryland State Police Academy (June 25, 2007 to December 21, 2007) -I am trained to administer Standardized Field Sobriety Tests through NHTSA and the Maryland State Police (MSP Academy, June 25, 2007 to December 21, 2007). -I have attended and graduated from the University of Maryland University College Advanced DUI College (UMUC January 7-11, 2013). -Street Narcotics Investigation for Road Patrol (MPCTC, 05/22/2015) -I have attended and completed training Enhanced DUI Enforcement: The Complete Arrest (MPCTC, 05/11/2016). -A.R.I.D.E.: Advanced Roadside Impaired Driving Enforcement (MPCTC, 03/29-03/30/2017) -Cannabis Impairment Detection Workshop (MPCTC, 09/29/2021) Driver: MD DL MD10272526623 AUSTIN COLE HAYNES 1169 CANON WAY WESTMINSTER, MD 21157 2/M, DOB 03/16/2001 301-305-3939 Phase I: Reason for Contact: On 01/28/2023 at approximately 1417 hours I was on duty, in uniform, operating a marked Maryland State Police Patrol vehicle, G-39. I responded to the arear of W/B MD 140 at Sandymount Rd, Finksburg, Carroll County, MD, for a report of a possible impaired driver. I was advised by MSP Westminster dispatch the vehicle made a left turn onto Sandymount Rd, toward Old Westminster Pike, then W/B on Old Westminster Pike, then S/B on Bollinger Rd. I was able to located the vehicle, described as a white 2013 Buick 4 door passenger car with Maryland tags 3BY0131, S/B on Bollinger Rd, N/O Hook Rd. I was able to observe the vehicle drive with the driver side tires over the double yellow center line, and initiated a traffic stop on that vehicle by activating my patrol vehicles emergency equipment (specifically my overhead red and blue lights). The vehicle came to a stop off of the roadway, in front of 1420 Bollinger Rd, Finksburg, Carroll County, MD. The weather was cloudy and approximately 50 degrees Fahrenheit. Phase II: Contact: I approached the vehicle on the drivers side of the vehicle. The window was already down and I immediately detected a strong odor of an alcoholic beverage emanating from the passenger compartment of the vehicle. I was able to observe the vehicle was occupied by a white male driver. I made contact with the driver, identified myself, advised the stop was being recorded, and stated the reasons for the traffic stop. I made the following observations of the driver: -eyes glassy and bloodshot -strong odor of alcoholic beverage emanating from the drivers breath and vehicles passenger compartment -moderate odor of burnt marijuana emanating from the passenger compartment of the vehicle -driver was wearing purple sneakers, gray pants, and black t-shirt I recognized the odor of marijuana based on my training, experience, and knowledge gained with the Maryland State Police. I asked the driver how long ago had he last consumed marijuana. The driver advised probable about, uh, 9 oclock (9am). I did observe the drivers Maryland Medical cannabis card, which he did display upon request. The driver initially not able to locate his drivers license. The driver was identified by name and date of birth (subsequently verified by MVA photo comparison and his located MD DL) to be AUSTIN COLE HAYNES, DOB 03/16/2001. I had the driver exit the vehicle to separate him from the odor emanating from the vehicle, and to conduct a probable cause search of the vehicle based on the odor of marijuana emanating from the vehicle. The driver did admit to the presence of marijuana in the vehicle. I asked the driver if he was on medications and he stated he is on anti-depressants (last taken between 8-9am today, dosage recently adjusted). I conducted a detailed search of the vehicle, based on the detected and recognized odor of marijuana emanating from the vehicle. The following items were located and seized: A. one red colored grinder, containing item B, located in front of the gear shift B. green plant matter (marijuana), 6.6 grams The grinder and its contents were not labeled as THC or marijuana, or with the drivers name and/ or Maryland Medical Cannabis patient number as required. The items were seized, documented on MSP Form 67 and 63 (P-323237), and subsequently submitted to the MSP Westminster Barrack evidence locker. The plant matter was recognized through my training and experience with the Maryland State Police to be marijuana (a Controlled Dangerous Substance of Schedule 1). Addition marijuana was located in the vehicle, however, was properly labeled as required. Per the current agreement with the CCSAO, the driver was not charged with the marijuana violation. The driver was able to provide his MD DL after finally locating it within his wallet. I had the driver move to the approximately level driveway of 1420 Bollinger Rd for further questions. Q. Do you know the name of the anti-depressants youre taking? A. Amitriptyline, Welbutrin, the driver could not recall the name of the third medication. Q. How long ago was the dosing last adjusted? A. About three days ago. Q. When did you last consume marijuana? A. Between 8 and 9 am. Q. How often do you consume marijuana? A. Normally in the evenings, I clarified my question and the driver advised about three times a week for how often he consumes marijuana. The driver advised has been more stressed in the mornings and has been smoking more in the morning. The driver did state I use it more than an average person should. Q. Do you wear contacts or glasses? A. No, sir. Q. Do you have any physical issues that would prevent you from standing on one leg for approximately 30 seconds or walking a straight line heel touching toe? A. No, sir. Q. Have you consumed any alcoholic beverages today? A. No, sir. Q. How about last night? A. Yes, sir. Q. How long ago was your last alcoholic drink last night? A. Uh, over 12 hours ago, definitely before 2 am. While speaking with the driver, I made the following observations: -strong odor of alcoholic beverage on breath and person -eyes glassy and bloodshot -moderate odor of burnt marijuana on breath and person Based on my observations of the driver, the traffic violation I observed, and drivers admittance of consuming medications w/ marijuana, I made the decision to administer the Standardized Field Sobriety Tests. The driver consented to the SFSTs. Phase III: Pre-Arrest Screening: SFSTs: All tests were explained and demonstrated prior to me asking the driver to attempt them. Horizontal Gaze Nystagmus: The drivers eyes displayed equal pupil size, tracking, and reaction. I was able to observe 6 out of the 6 potential clues: -both eyes lacked smooth pursuit -both eyes displayed distinct and sustained nystagmus at maximum deviation -both eyes displayed onset of nystagmus prior to 45 degree deviation Additional observations: -strong odor of alcoholic beverage on breath and person -eyes glassy and bloodshot -moderate odor of burnt marijuana on breath and person -slight side to side sway, approximately to 1 inch -driver had to be reminded to keep his head still Vertical Nystagmus was observed. Walk Turn: The driver conducted this test with his shoes on. I observed 5 clues out of the potential 8 clues: -stepped out the instructional position 3 times -incorrect turn: turned to the right not left as instructed and demonstrated, turn not executed the way demonstrated and instructed -stopped walking after the turn to confirm next portion of the test -sidestepped/ stepped offline for balance on second set of steps 3 times on second set of steps -missed heel to toe twice on second set of steps Additional observations: -strong odor of alcoholic beverage on breath and person -eyes glassy and bloodshot -moderate odor of burnt marijuana on breath and person One Leg Stand: The driver conducted this test with his shoes on. The driver indicated he understood my instructions. The driver stood on his left foot and raised his right. I observed 1 out of the 4 potential clues: -the driver swayed front to back and side to side during the test approximately 1 inch Additional observations: -strong odor of alcoholic beverage on breath and person -eyes glassy and bloodshot -moderate odor of burnt marijuana on breath and person Additional Tests: A.R.I.D.E. Lack of Convergence: The lack of convergence was present: right eye diverged from center Additional observations: -strong odor of alcoholic beverage on breath and person -eyes glassy and bloodshot -moderate odor of burnt marijuana on breath and person Finger To Nose: The driver was placed in the instructional position: arms down to their side, heels together, hands in fists with index fingers extended and wrists rotated outward. The driver was instructed, when told to do so, to close their eyes and tilt their head backward. I would then give the command, either right or left, and the driver is to touch the tip of their nose with the tip of their index finger, then immediately bring their arm back down to their side. I provided the following commands: left, right, left, right, right, left. Observations: -swayed side to side and front to back during the test -missed tip of nose: touched upper lip, right nostril, -held finger in place for a few seconds -used pad of finger not fingertip as demonstrated and instructed -strong odor of alcoholic beverage on breath and person -eyes glassy and bloodshot -moderate odor of burnt marijuana on breath and person Modified Romberg: The driver was placed in the instructional position: arms down to their side and heels together. The driver was instructed when I would tell them to do so, to close their eyes, tilt their head back and estimate the passage of 30 seconds by counting quietly to themselves. After the passage of 30 seconds, the driver was instructed to bring their head down, open their eyes and say done. Observations: -during the test, the driver swayed front to back and side to side approximately 1 inch -the driver took 29 seconds (according to the digital recording) to estimate the passage of 30 seconds -eyelid tremors observed -strong odor of alcoholic beverage on breath and person -eyes glassy and bloodshot -moderate odor of burnt marijuana on breath and person The driver was offered a Preliminary Breath Test, which he agreed to take. The result of the PBT was 0.11 BrAC. I asked the driver what was he drinking, and the driver advised he was drinking mixed drinks while house sitting. Based on my observations of the driver during contact and the SFSTs, I made the decision to place the driver under arrest for DUI. The driver was advised he was under arrest, handcuffed, and placed in the front seat of my patrol vehicle for transport to the MSP Westminster Barrack. Upon arrival at the MSP Westminster Barrack, the driver was read the DR15 Advice of Rights at 1518 hours. The driver signed the DR15 at 1530 hours, agreeing to submit to the intoximeter. The intoximeter was administered by Sgt Gibson. The result of the intoximeter was 0.11 BrAC per 210 liters of breath at 1540 hours. The driver was issued the DR15, MSP Form 33, DR15A, Notice to Appear, Notice of Right to Counsel, and traffic citations L300DJH-L360DJH. The driver was released to a sober driver: his parents. At all times the driver was polite, respectful, and cooperative. All events occurred in Carroll County, MD. Case closed on arrest.
